item.title: Overwatch 2 Just Teased A Long-Awaited Hero And Fans Are Freaking Out
item.content:encoded:
https://kotaku.com/overwatch-2-emre-sarioglu-freja-animated-trailer-who-is-1851771309

Overwatch 2‚Äôs next hero is Freja, and the crossbow-wielding damage character is getting an early trial period this weekend. To celebrate, Blizzard released a new animated trailer featuring her doing some sick acrobatic tricks and taking out synthetic omnic goons. That‚Äôs all well and good, but what fans are honing in on are the final moments in which Freja is given a bounty hunting contract that hints at a long-awaited character finally making their debut. However, if you‚Äôre not super tuned into Overwatch lore, you might have no idea who he is.

Emre Sarioglu is a Turkish hero from the titular organization‚Äôs heyday before the events of the games, and has appeared only a few times in the series‚Äô extended lore. His most prominent appearance is in a group photo of much of the OG team with a young Pharah; otherwise he‚Äôs mostly only been seen in the margins of the lore in things like the Overwatch: Declassified book. Sojourn has a voice line in Overwatch 2 saying Emre wanted to retire to Havana, but that‚Äôs pretty much it. The guy‚Äôs mostly an enigma, and that mystery has made him a bit of a running joke within the Overwatch community. Now, however, it seems like Blizzard may actually be bringing him into the fold with Freja, and fans are losing it.

While it‚Äôs exciting that we might finally learn more about Emre, it‚Äôs unclear if this thread will be picked up any time soon. Overwatch loves to introduce characters in external media and then not get back to them for several years. For example, Mauga was first introduced in the short story What You Left Behind in 2019 and wasn‚Äôt added to the roster until Overwatch 2‚Äôs eighth season in 2023. At the very least we know Blizzard hasn‚Äôt completely forgotten him.

Freja‚Äôs test period will last from March 21 to 24; she‚Äôll then officially join the roster in season 16 on April 22.

item.title: LightSpeed Studios unveils original IP strategy, including new AAA action game by Hideaki Itsuno
item.content:encoded:
https://www.gematsu.com/2025/03/lightspeed-studios-unveils-original-ip-strategy-including-new-aaa-action-game-by-hideaki-itsuno

LightSpeed Studios has revealed its ‚ÄúOriginal IP Initiative,‚Äù a new strategic focus centered on developing original titles, including an AAA original action game by Hideaki Itsuno.

Get the details below.

LightSpeed Studios Commits to Development of Original Game Intellectual Property

Recognizing that innovation drives player engagement, LightSpeed Studios is sharpening its approach and announcing its commitment to empowering a network of self-sustained, independently run regional studios that will be focused entirely on developing original, cross-platform game titles.

LightSpeed Studios, best known for its work with established game title PUBG MOBILE (co-developed with KRAFTON), is strategically expanding and building state-of-the-art development facilities around the world to support original game development.

This strategy enables its development studios, which notably includes LightSpeed LA, the newly established LightSpeed Japan Studio, along with teams across the world, a direct pipeline to LightSpeed Studios‚Äô centralized technical resources. This consists of LightSpeed Studios‚Äô latest research and development breakthroughs, which push the boundaries of graphics and performance to enhance in-game realism, as showcased in workshops during GDC 2025.

LightSpeed Studios Sets the Stage for a New Era for LightSpeed Japan Studio

Building on this approach, legendary game director and head of LightSpeed Japan Studio, Hideaki Itsuno, is revealing at GDC 2025 that he‚Äôs entering the arena and embarked on the early stages of bringing his own visionary AAA game title to life. Drawing on his extensive experience directing games and building incredible teams at Capcom that drove the remarkable successes of Devil May Cry, the Capcom Alpha series, Capcom VS. SNK, and many more iconic game titles, Itsuno is ready to apply the same principles of creative freedom, efficiency, and humility to assemble an outstanding team and create something truly groundbreaking.

‚ÄúWe‚Äôre building a creative environment that combines diverse cultural perspectives with cutting-edge technology,‚Äù said LightSpeed Japan Studio general manager Hideaki Itsuno. ‚ÄúOur focus is on developing gameplay elements that offer players entirely new experiences‚Äîthe kind of innovations that make players say I‚Äôve never seen that in a game before.‚Äù

Leveraging Global Talent and Nurturing Creative Freedom

Additionally, to foster fresh perspectives in original game development, LightSpeed Studios is adopting a model that enables each studio to shape its own culture, advocating for original thinking within teams. Bringing to the table Eastern and Western game philosophies, LightSpeed Studios is positioned to encourage regional teams to exchange ideas, blend cultural influences, and unite under a shared vision‚Äîcreating truly global gaming experiences.

A standout example of this approach is being led by the vice president of LightSpeed Studios, Steve C. Martin, known for his commitment to five-year development cycles. Focused on bringing his original AAA open world action title, Last Sentinel, to life, Steve has assembled a world-class, global team. Despite talent from prestigious studios like Rockstar Games, Meta and EA Games, LightSpeed LA has fostered not only a culture of creative freedom but ensures product efficiency, thanks to Steve‚Äôs emphasis on humility and a willingness to embrace constructive feedback.

‚ÄúAny game studio‚Äôs ambition lies with developing original games,‚Äù said Martin. ‚ÄúThe creative freedom of creating your own lore from scratch, building a compelling narrative, and all the upsides from this is the dream of any studio, and that‚Äôs why LightSpeed Studios is the place to be.‚Äù

item.title: The Last of Us Part II Remastered PC System Requirements Revealed; RTX 4080, RX 7900 XT Recommended For 4K@60 FPS
item.content:encoded:
https://wccftech.com/the-last-of-us-part-ii-remastered-pc-system-requirements-revealed-rtx-4080-rx-7900-xt-recommended-for-4k60-fps/

The Last of Us Part II Remastered PC system requirements have been revealed today, detailing the system requirements for different resolutions and target framerates.

To run the game at low settings, 720p resolution @ 30 frames per second, users won't need a beefy system, as either an Intel Core i3-8100 or AMD Ryzen 3 1300X CPU and either a GTX 1650 or RX 5500XT will be enough. To run the game at the very high graphics preset, 4K resolution @ 60 frames per second, on the other hand, a more powerful system powered by either an Intel Core i7-11700 or AMD Ryzen 7 5700X CPU and either an RTX 4080 or RX 7900 XT GPU, as well as 32 GB RAM. You can find the full system requirements below.

The PC version of The Last of Us Part II Remastered will also come with plenty of PC-exclusive features, including NVIDIA DLSS 3 Super Resolution, AMD FSR 3.1 and AMD FSR 4 support for both upscaling and frame generation, uncapped framerate, DirectStorage support, and more. The game will also support 21:9, 32:9, and 48:9 resolutions.

Besides the features above, the PC version of The Last of Us Part II Remastered will also feature additional content for the No Return mode, such as two new playable characters - Bill and Marlene from The Last of Us Part I - and four new maps. These additions are also coming to the PlayStation 5 version with a new update launching on the same day the PC version releases.

The Last of Us Part II Remastered launches on PC on April 3rd. You can learn more about the definitive version of Naughty Dog's game by checking out my review of the PS5 release.

item.title: Make Sure You Get Your Blacksmith Right Away In Assassin‚Äôs Creed Shadows
item.content:encoded:
https://kotaku.com/assassins-creed-shadows-blacksmith-upgrade-engrave-1851771284

Like any open-world game, it can take a second to get your bearings in Assassin‚Äôs Creed Shadows. After the game‚Äôs opening act, your first line of business is to find Tomiko and establish your hideout. This is your base of operations where you‚Äôll accrue allies and build facilities, though you‚Äôll quickly find one of the most valuable ones is locked off: the Forge. You‚Äôll see that this building has the prerequisite ‚ÄúRecruit a Blacksmith,‚Äù so naturally, you‚Äôll want to knock that off your to-do list.

Suggested Reading

The Week In Games: What‚Äôs Coming Out Beyond Assassin's Creed Mirage

  • Off
  • English

Suggested Reading

To get your own blacksmith, look for the quest ‚ÄúWay Of The Blacksmith‚Äù in the Objectives tab of your main menu under Tomiko‚Äôs icon. You might recall that Tomiko mentions recruiting a blacksmith named Heiji in the cutscene where she and Naoe discuss the first two Onryo to hunt, so you‚Äôll almost certainly have access to this quest if you‚Äôre reading this. Of course, assuming you‚Äôre playing on the game‚Äôs default settings, you‚Äôll have to do a tiny bit of legwork to track Heiji down, so you can check out his location below if you just want to get to him right away.

‚ÄôThe Way Of The Blacksmith‚Äô quest location

As the game‚Äôs hints directly indicate, Heiji is located in Sekai. You‚Äôll find this area directly southwest of the hideout. Sekai is also where you‚Äôll begin your hunt for the Golden Teppo, so you can kill two birds with one stone by going there first. Well, technically you kill one bird and recruit another bird, but you get the picture.

Once you arrive, you‚Äôll find Heiji under attack by a group of bandits. They‚Äôre common foes, so dispatch them however you please; you can easily complete this battle even if you‚Äôve not bothered to level up or grab new equipment. Talk with Hieji after the battle and you‚Äôll learn about the circumstances that have broken his spirit. Pick whichever dialogue option feels best to you, and Heiji will make his way to Tomiko‚Äôs hideout. Once you gather enough resources, you‚Äôll finally be able to build a forge at your hideout.

How to best use the Blacksmith

With the Forge now built, run to wherever you parked your shiny new building and look for Heiji. Upon talking with him, you‚Äôll have access to the following options:

Upgrade: Invest resources into any piece of equipment to increase its level. Equipment cannot be higher than your character‚Äôs level (level equivalent gear simply won‚Äôt appear). You can use Gold to immediately upgrade a piece of equipment to your current level, but Gold is a rare resource that should not be confused with normal currency (Mon). Save your Gold for bigger upgrades down the road; don‚Äôt use it by accident in the early game!

Engrave: Apply one of your found Engravings to an applicable piece of gear (it will say ‚ÄúVisit the Hideout‚Äôs blacksmith to engrave a perk‚Äù under its stats). Engravings are not consumed upon use and can be overridden, though note this process will consume Mon every time.

Salvage: Break down a piece of gear into upgrade materials.

In short, if you find a great piece of gear that proves essential to your build, come here to refine it as you play to keep its stats relevant. And if you‚Äôre just beginning your journey in Assassin‚Äôs Creed Shadows, be sure to keep some resources on hand for when Yasuke joins your party!

item.title: Shadows Has Almost Beaten The Entire Series on Steam in One Day
item.content:encoded:
https://insider-gaming.com/shadows-has-almost-beaten-the-entire-series-on-steam-in-one-day/

Assassin‚Äôs Creed Shadows is Ubisoft‚Äôs first Day One release on Steam it‚Äôs already climbed the platform‚Äôs all-time player peak charts to become third in series history. 

According to SteamDB (via Games Radar), Assassin‚Äôs Creed Shadows is off to a great start on Steam, achieving an all-time player peak of 41,412 on the first day (at the time of writing). To compare, Shadows has more than doubled AC Valhalla‚Äôs numbers, which peaked at 15,679 2.3 years ago. It is less than 150 players away from beating AC Origins‚Äô peak, 41,551, which arrived 7.4 years ago. AC Odyssey still stands strong at the moment, peaking at 62,069 6.4 years ago. 

Regarding AC Shadows reviews on Steam, things seem to be going well for Ubisoft, with the platform categorising it as ‚ÄúVery Positive‚Äù. If you are interested in an in-depth review of Assassin‚Äôs Creed Shadows, you can check out Insider Gaming‚Äôs review of the title, where we described the game as ‚ÄúGreat, But The Blade Still Needs Sharpening‚Äù. 

Assassin‚Äôs Creed Shadows is the latest instalment of Ubisoft‚Äôs popular series. For those unaware of the game, the new setting takes players to Feudal Japan, where they explore a fresh narrative set in a vast open world through the eyes of dual protagonists.

The new protagonists are Yasuke and Naoe, both featuring distinct playstyles. One is a stealthy Assassin, and the other is a legendary Samurai; players must master both characters to take down enemies with precision and power. The game also introduces a fully customisable hideout where you train your crew, craft/upgrade weapons, and interact with characters. 

In other news, the Japanese government worries about ‚Äòimitation attacks‚Äô based on Assassin‚Äôs Creed Shadows. Also, here‚Äôs where to find all the Legendary Animals in the game. What are your thoughts on AC Shadows almost beating the entire series on Steam in one day? Let us know in the comments or on our community forum!

item.title: Why a New Domain Discovery Is Getting Persona 4 Fans Excited For a Possible Remake
item.content:encoded:
https://www.ign.com/articles/why-a-new-domain-discovery-is-getting-persona-4-fans-excited-for-a-possible-remake

After the success of Persona 3 Reload, it's easy to see why fans would hope for Atlus to move ahead to its next entry in the Persona series. Now, with the discovery of a domain registration, hopes that we'll see a Persona 4 remake are that much higher.

Spotted by YouTuber Faz, a domain for "p4re.jp" was recently registered. While normally not something to get excited about, Faz noted that several years ago, "p3re.jp" was registered a few months before the official reveal of Persona 3 Reload.

p4re. jp was registered a few hours ago.

2 years ago, p3re. jp was registered. 3 months later Persona 3 Reload was revealed pic.twitter.com/FjuhAkr76q

‚Äî Faz (@ScrambledFaz) March 20, 2025

Rumors of a Persona 4 remake have swirled around the gaming sphere for a while, but a domain does lend a bit more credence to the idea. Though it's not the only older game in the Persona series that could use a refresh ‚Äî the Persona 2 duology, in particular would be nice to see ‚Äî Persona 4 and the enhanced Vita port Persona 4 Golden do hold a special place in many RPG players' hearts.

Persona 3 Reload successfully brought the PlayStation 2 classic to new audiences, becoming one of the fastest-selling games in Atlus history. Add on the eminent popularity of Persona 5 and its Royal edition, and a Persona 4 remake would make a lot of sense.

Still, nothing's been confirmed or even teased yet on Atlus' side. While a domain registration certainly feels like it could be the canary in the Persona mines, we'll have to see if this pans out or not.

Eric is a freelance writer for IGN.

item.title: The Last of Us Part II Remastered for PC to launch alongside new playable characters and maps for ‚ÄòNo Return‚Äô mode
item.content:encoded:
https://www.gematsu.com/2025/03/the-last-of-us-part-ii-remastered-for-pc-to-launch-alongside-new-playable-characters-and-maps-for-no-return-mode

Two New Characters

Two new characters are being introduced for the mode‚ÄîThe Last of Us Part I‚Äòs Bill and Marlene. Like with each No Return combatant, these characters offer their own unique playstyles, and should offer both new and returning fans an exciting new opportunity to test their mettle.

  • Bill is a ‚ÄúSmuggler‚Äù playstyle who can access a custom pump shotgun from dead drops, and receives double rewards from drops as well. He‚Äôs stronger against melee attacks but can‚Äôt dodge.
  • Marlene, meanwhile, features a ‚ÄúRisk Taker‚Äù playstyle that includes a Custom Assault Rifle, ‚ÄúAll or Nothing‚Äù gambits, can reroute her No Return path once per run, and more.

Four New Maps

Four new maps have also been added to No Return.

  • Overlook, which is set high above the city of Seattle and features plenty of verticality, is the memorable site of a Seraphites encounter in the campaign.
  • School is, during the campaign, the abandoned elementary school in which Ellie and Dina face off against the W.L.F.
  • Streets is set in the overgrown Seattle neighborhood of Hillcrest.
  • Nest will be familiar to players who have played as Abby through an Infected-infested building.

PlayStation 5 Update

This new No Return content, as well as accompanying new Trophies and additional bug fixes ‚Äì will be available day-and-date with the PC launch via a free downloadable 2.0.0 patch.6

PlayStation Network Log-In Bonuses

The Last of Us Part II Remastered on PC will support PlayStation overlay and PSN Trophies with an optional account for PlayStation Network log-in.

While not required, those on PC who do sign in with their account for PlayStation Network will also gain access to 50 in-game points to activate bonus features, as well as a new skin for Ellie featuring Jordan A. Mun‚Äôs jacket from our new game in development for PlayStation 5, Intergalactic: The Heretic Prophet.

PC Features

The PC version of The Last of Us Part II Remastered brings with it all the improvements and new features added in the PlayStation 5 version released in 2024, such as the roguelike survival mode No Return, Guitar Free Play, and hours of developer commentary.

And in partnership with our friends at Nixxes Software and Iron Galaxy, The Last of Us Part II Remastered has been brought to PC with plenty of PC-centric quality-of-life features that further bring the snow-covered mountains of Jackson, Wyoming, and the rainswept streets of Seattle, Washington to beautiful life.

This version of The Last of Us Part II Remastered is optimized for PC with:

  • Nvidia DLSS 3 Super Resolution support1
  • AMD FSR 3.1 and AMD FSR 4 support with upscaling and frame generation1
  • VSync and framerate cap options, including an uncapped framerate option2
  • DirectStorage support, and more.

It has been developed with features designed specifically for PC, including:

  • Adjustable Texture Quality
  • LOD Distance Range
  • Volumetric Quality
  • Shadow Quality
  • Ambient Occlusion
  • Reflections Quality
  • And more

The Last of Us Part II Remastered on PC will feature support for Ultrawide monitors, so players will be able to take in the stunning vistas of Jackson and the harsh streets of Seattle with gameplay supported in 21:9 ultra-wide, 32:9 super ultra-wide and even 48:9 resolutions with compatibility for triple-monitor setups.

And take in every chapter of Ellie and Abby‚Äôs journeys in stunning 4K resolution while playing either via various supported controllers as well as keyboard and mouse controls. And immerse yourself in the story with 3D audio surrounding you in every tense moment of action and each quiet scene of exploration.

Keyboard and mouse control support includes a host of new control customization options, like full control remapping, primary and secondary bindings for keyboard and mouse control, an adaptive mode that allows players to combine keyboard and controller inputs, and more. Part II Remastered on PC will feature full gamepad support, while DualSense controllers are supported and feature full haptic feedback5.

As our team and partners have been hard at work on this version, we‚Äôll also be introducing a host of bug fixes and various improvements to offer as smooth a play experience as possible.

The Last of Us Part II Remastered on PC offers a wide range of graphics settings and presets, to ensure the best possible experience on hardware ranging from high-end PCs to handheld gaming devices. Below you‚Äôll find an overview of recommended specifications for a variety of graphics presets.

The Last of Us Part II Remastered first launched for PlayStation 5 on January 19, 2024.

GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

Free-to-play game Delta Force isn't playing around when it comes to cheaters. Developer Team Jade has revealed that 10-year bans--yes, a full decade--have been handed out recently to over 1,000 players for violating rules of the tactical shooter. The preventative measures don't stop there, either.

On X, the official Delta Force account shared statistics on how the developer is dealing with cheaters. From March 14-20, the game's security team said that 1,446 players were banned, 694 devices blocked, and more than 4,000 people forced offline. The Delta Force website notes that cheating can consist of "the use of plug-ins, illegal software, inappropriate behaviour, malicious use of exploits or bugs, etc." The developer also mentions a zero-tolerance policy, which checks out considering over 7,000 decade bans were dished out for Season Genesis in January.

Last month, Delta Force got a Black Hawk Down campaign that unexpectedly ended up being free. This add-on is actually a remake of the 2003 game of the same name. It's inspired by the Hollywood movie based on a real event that occurred in 1993, with the game featuring the Battle of Mogadishu. Meanwhile, the Warfare mode offers up 32-vs.-32 online multiplayer in the tactical shooter.

Delta Force launched on PC in December and landed on Steam's top titles for that month, alongside Indiana Jones and the Great Circle. The free-to-play game has seemingly maintained a healthy player base as well, with SteamDB showing over 52,000 concurrent players for Delta Force at the time of publication.

The tactical shooter is scheduled to get a mobile release on April 21. Afterward, Delta Force is planned to arrive later this year on PlayStation and Xbox consoles.

item.title: Retroid Pocket 5 Review ‚Äì ‚ÄúOne of the best gaming handhelds you can buy‚Äù
item.content:encoded:
https://www.thesixthaxis.com/2025/03/20/retroid-pocket-5-review-one-of-the-best-gaming-handhelds-you-can-buy/

Nintendo don‚Äôt want you to know this, but other handheld gaming platforms do still exist. While the Nintendo Switch is the apex predator of consoles you can take on holiday, there are now more alternatives than at any other time ‚Äì I feel like I should be whispering this in case Mario looms in the doorway, ready to enforce the big N‚Äôs will.

The Steam Deck, and portable PCs like the ROG Ally nab their own share of the food chain, but there‚Äôs a huge movement happening in the retro handheld space. Here, companies like Anbernic and Powkiddy are breaking new ground, with Chinese manufacturers focusing on reuniting gamers with the best titles of yesteryear. The Retroid Pocket 5 is the latest from Retroid, offering a luxurious, fully featured handheld that isn‚Äôt just for old games.

The Retroid Pocket 5‚Äôs design owes some level of gratitude to the Sony employees who worked on the PlayStation Vita. In the black colour scheme of our review unit, it could almost be 2012 all over again, but since the Vita was a classy and sleek device that was ahead of its time, those visual similarities aren‚Äôt a bad thing.

The Pocket 5 gains some extra curvature at the rear, and that‚Äôs definitely not something to complain about. It makes it much more comfortable to hold than either the Vita or the Nintendo Switch. It‚Äôs still a small console though, so depending on the size of your hands, you may run the risk of developing cramp. Personally, I had no problems.

Once you‚Äôve powered the Retroid Pocket 5 up, it‚Äôs obvious that this is a thoroughly new and modern device, not least thanks to the RGB lights that encircle each analogue stick. The physical form of the Pocket 5 makes it just about pocket-friendly, but compared to devices like the Steam Deck and Nintendo Switch, it‚Äôs a true handheld, and something that you can pack in your bag without thinking about if you need to sacrifice something else to make space.

You probably should treat it with some care, though, as the Retroid Pocket 5 is $219/¬£180, which, while cheaper than some of the top-end retro-flavoured devices, is still a significant investment. You want to know that this thing will last you several years, and in terms of build quality, it feels as though the Retroid Pocket 5 will last you through many, many replays of Final Fantasy 7 or Panzer Dragoon Saga.

All of the expected controls are here, from the four main face buttons, albeit with the letters in a Nintendo Switch layout rather than the more common Xbox one (though you can set it to emulate one in the settings) to the D-pad and dual analogue sticks. The sticks are excellent, boasting that much-desired Hall Effect tech to ensure they don‚Äôt wear out for a very long time. Though they‚Äôre relatively small, they feel great in use, and I was consistently surprised by how responsive they were.

The shoulder buttons and triggers are amongst the best I‚Äôve found on a handheld, the shoulders boasting gloriously clicky microswitches, and true analogue triggers beneath them. The triggers have a remarkable level of activation, especially considering what they‚Äôre attached to. If you‚Äôre a fan of racing games they‚Äôre a top-tier inclusion that you don‚Äôt tend to get in the retro-handheld space.

While the Pocket 5‚Äôs physical build is sleek and stylish, the specs under the hood continue to impress. The main point of excitement is the 5.5-inch OLED screen, which runs at 1080p and 60Hz. It‚Äôs bright, it‚Äôs vibrant, and on the black model it seamlessly blends into the body of the console. With a widescreen aspect, you‚Äôre able to play games from multiple generations, as well as watch content via a streaming service as well.

The reason that you‚Äôre going to be able to do that is that the Retroid Pocket 5 runs on Android 13. You can install all of your favourite Android apps and games, using the touchscreen as the interface, and if games support it, you can also use the physical controls, which function like any other Bluetooth controller.

Thanks to the Snapdragon 865 chipset and 8GB of RAM, you can play all of the most challenging Android games right now, and I enjoyed jumping into Genshin Impact, Zenless Zone Zero and Infinity Nikki, all of which ran fantastically. Being able to play with physical controls helped to make them feel better than ever, and utterly unlike mobile phone games.

If you‚Äôre interested in the Retroid Pocket 5 though, chances are you‚Äôre here for retro games. Now, we‚Äôre not going to get into the muddy waters of emulation, ROMs and ownership here, but legally speaking, you should own a copy of a game for you to use the ROM of it. We‚Äôve got a healthy collection of older games stashed in boxes and cupboards, so this is a perfect way (and excuse) to revisit some classics. But they don‚Äôt have to be too retro.

The Pocket 5 is powerful, particularly in the context of Android retro devices, and that means that it‚Äôs capable of emulating systems up to and including the Dreamcast, PlayStation 2, GameCube and even some Nintendo Switch games. With 128GB of internal storage, there‚Äôs plenty of space for those ROMs as a starting point, but there‚Äôs also a MicroSD expansion slot which will allow you to carry a huge library of retro games around with you on the go.

It comes with a host of emulators already installed, but you‚Äôll have to do some legwork if you want to make everything look and feel more like a coherent console experience. My favourite frontend is ES-DE, and while you have to subscribe and download that from their website rather than Goggle Play, there‚Äôs plenty of guides online if you‚Äôre stuck. The finicky nature of this process isn‚Äôt unique to the Pocket 5, but if you‚Äôre after a simple experience, other retro-flavoured consoles are more straightforward. They likely do less, though.

With a little work, the retro gaming experience on the Retroid Pocket 5 is fantastic, not least thanks to the incredible screen and the excellent controls. Returning to games like Sonic Adventure 2, Virtua Tennis and Metropolis Street Racer ‚Äì alright, I‚Äôm a Dreamcast nut ‚Äì looks and feels incredible, and you‚Äôll marvel that a handheld this size can now play games that used to need a full home console to play. It‚Äôs nostalgic and it‚Äôs part of video game preservation ‚Äì what more could you want?

Well, you might want to play modern console games, and the Retroid Pocket 5 actually has you covered there too, thanks to the wonders of streaming. You can stream PS5, Xbox Series X, and PC titles to the Pocket 5 with very little hassle, positioning it as one of the absolute best handheld devices out right now. I played a bunch of Yakuza: Like A Dragon on Game Pass, and most of the time it felt like I was playing it natively. Thanks to the 5000mAh battery and the smartphone innards, it also lasted far longer than any other handheld device I own, making the Steam Deck and the ROG Ally look pathetic in terms of battery life.

I love the Retroid Pocket 5‚Äôs form factor. I‚Äôm a little tired of the Nintendo Switch and the ROG Ally taking up as much of my bag as they do, and while not only taking up less space, the Pocket 5 will outlast them by hours upon hours. If you‚Äôre after the biggest hit of nostalgia there‚Äôs a purple Gamecube-styled colourway, a Grey SNES-inspired one, and then the white or black options. The black one is exceedingly sleek though, and looks like a true premium device. If you‚Äôre interested in something similar, but without the full outlay, the Retroid Pocket 3 and 4 are still excellent retro handhelds. Alternatively, if you‚Äôre able to spend more, don‚Äôt care about size, and want to add native PC gaming, it‚Äôs hard to fault the Steam Deck OLED.

item.title: Persona 4 Remake Potentially Confirmed by New Domain Registration
item.content:encoded:
https://techraptor.net/gaming/news/persona-4-remake-domain-registration

An eagle-eyed social media user has spotted the registration of a brand new web domain that could point towards the existence (and possible imminent reveal) of a Persona 4 remake.

As spotted by YouTuber Faz on X, the domain "p4re.jp" was registered earlier today. The registrant is listed as "not displayed by registrant's request", which could well be an attempt on publisher Atlus' part to obfuscate the Persona 4 remake until it's time for the game to be revealed.

Faz points out that two years ago, the domain "p3re.jp" was registered in a similar fashion, and three months after that domain was registered, Persona 3 Reload was officially revealed. We could well be about to see a repeat of that particular pattern.

Of course, the domain registration isn't necessarily concrete evidence that a Persona 4 remake is on the way, nor is it a guarantee that Atlus or Sega were the ones who registered the domain.

Still, the fact that Persona 3 Reload was preceded by a similar registration perhaps makes this more compelling evidence than the usual rumor mill. I, for one, am hoping against hope that we are indeed about to get Persona 4 Reload.

If it is happening, then we may well get a reveal during one of the upcoming Summer Games Fest showcases; Persona 3 Reload was, after all, announced during 2023's Xbox summer show.

Another reveal during an Xbox show could also mean that Persona 4 Reload lands on Game Pass on day one, which would be another blessing for subscribers. Of course, all of this is speculation at the moment.

We will, of course, have to wait and see whether a Persona 4 remake is in the offing. Luckily, even if it's not, you can still pick up the enhanced re-release Persona 4 Golden right now for PC, PlayStation 4 (and PS5 via backwards compatibility), Xbox, and Nintendo Switch.

item.title: Assassin's Creed Shadows Update Makes Key Changes To Shrines Amid Cultural Sensitivity Discussion
item.content:encoded:
https://www.gamespot.com/articles/assassins-creed-shadows-update-makes-key-changes-to-shrines-amid-cultural-sensitivity-discussion/1100-6530252/?ftag=CAD-01-10abi2f

GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

An update for Assassin's Creed Shadows on launch day makes a couple key changes to the game's shrines, preventing players from destroying certain items in them. The patch comes amid a discussion about cultural sensitivity in the 16th-century Japan game.

According to IGN, the update changes the game so that the monks inside of the shrines no longer bleed when attacked, while tables and racks throughout the game's temples and shrines are now indestructible. Bowls and drums can be broken, however, and tables can be moved and pushed.

Earlier this week, Japan's Prime Minister Shigeru Ishiba responded to a question about Assassin's Creed Shadows and its shrines. He said, as translated by IGN, that "defacing a shrine is out of the question--it is an insult to the nation itself. Respecting the culture and religion of a country is fundamental, and we must make it clear that we will not simply accept acts that disregard them."

Hiroyuki Kada, a Japanese politician, said he fears that if people can vandalize a shrine in Assassin's Creed Shadows, it might "encourage similar behavior in real life."

"Shrine officials and local residents are also worried about this. Of course, freedom of expression must be respected, but acts that demean local cultures should be avoided," he said.

A viral video posted earlier this year showed a player running through a shrine and causing havoc. This was not an objective of any specific quest, but instead the player choosing to do this.

In July 2024, Ubisoft put out a statement in which it said Shadows is a work of fiction, and one that Ubisoft enlisted the help of external consultants, historians, and researchers as part of an effort to "inform our creative choices." Ubisoft also acknowledged that some of the game's promotional materials at the time "caused concern within the Japanese community," and for that, Ubisoft said, "We sincerely apologize."

Shadows is out now on PC, PS5, and Xbox Series X|S, featuring the protagonists Naoe and Yasuke. For more, check out GameSpot's Assassin's Creed Shadows review and our guides hub to help you get started. You can also find out how the game looks and performs on PS5 Pro.

item.title: Report: Valnet Blacklisted Freelancers Who Complained About Pay Rates
item.content:encoded:
https://aftermath.site/valnet-report-freelance

We wrote about Valnet‚Äôs low pay rates in a previous article about how underpaid freelancers are propping up games journalism. Today, new reporting by The Wrap shines more light on what‚Äôs going on behind the scenes of the owner of sites such as GameRant, The Gamer, and DualShockers.

The Wrap‚Äôs article focuses more on Valnet‚Äôs entertainment sites than gaming, talking to people who‚Äôve written for sites like Collider and MovieWeb. A former Valnet contributor told The Wrap that Valnet "present themselves as a safe haven for young and experienced writers, but they end up paying bargain-basement rates and forcing contractors to create junky clickbait.‚Äù

The Wrap reports that Valnet maintains a spreadsheet of ‚Äúblacklisted freelancers,‚Äù which for 2025 contains over 400 names of writers barred from writing for the company for offenses such as posting Valnet rates on social media, calling rates ‚Äúabysmal,‚Äù and suggesting Valnet put rates in job listings.

The Wrap also writes that, after a Valnet contributor filed a lawsuit against the company‚Äôs labor practices, Valnet asked contractors to sign releases promising not to join any class actions against the company. In exchange, they would receive $100. After few people accepted, Valnet bumped the offer to $200. 

It‚Äôs no surprise that Valnet relies on a network of low-paid freelancers, a depressingly common practice across plenty of online sites. People who spoke to The Wrap say that after Valnet acquired their sites, freelance rates dropped dramatically, and that ‚Äúaccess to health insurance and benefits evaporated as full-time employees were rehired as at-will contractors.‚Äù

Valnet built its name on acquiring sites and continues to seek more, The Wrap reports, another common strategy in online media these days. Nothing in here is particularly surprising, which is what makes it so depressing. As journalism jobs dwindle, especially in games journalism, these kinds of practices  may unfortunately become even more prevalent.

It‚Äôs hard to know what to do around any of this, especially when writing jobs are so thin on the ground and the cost of living continues to rise. If you're looking for a place to start, the Freelance Solidarity Project has guides and resources for freelancers, and some states and cities have passed ‚Äúfreelance isn‚Äôt free‚Äù acts that strive to protect freelancers from misclassifications, delayed payments, and more.

item.title: Hideo Kojima Addresses ‚ÄúOnline Negativity‚Äù Over Lowest-Rated Metal Gear Solid Game in The Series
item.content:encoded:
https://insider-gaming.com/hideo-kojima-addresses-online-negativity-over-lowest-rated-metal-gear-solid-game-in-the-series/

Nearly 11 years after its release, Hideo Kojima has taken to X to express his feelings over the negative feedback that Metal Gear Solid Ground Zeroes received when it was released.

Hideo Kojima is one of the finest auteurs of his generation across all mediums. His calculated approach to cinematic presentation and innovation has accompanied the director across his multi-decade career. Metal Gear Solid is arguably his crowning achievement, and many of the entries are some of the most heralded releases in the annals of gaming history.

One entry has proved divisive. Although it‚Äôs looked upon more favorably in hindsight, Ground Zeroes was the subject of much criticism when it first launched.

Metal Gear Solid Ground Zeroes was considered a ‚ÄúPrologue to the new gameplay‚Äù of Metal Gear Solid Phantom Pain, and it was originally supposed to be part of The Phantom Pain. However, as Kojima puts it in his statement on X: ‚ÄúThe PS4 was released and there were only a few titles out, so just GZ was released ahead of the others.‚Äù

Kojima and Konami opted to release it as a standalone piece of bite-sized action, and Ground Zeroes looked and played incredibly‚Äîthanks to the new and improved Fox Engine. But its brief runtime was an inescapable negative at the time.

Reflecting, Kojima has said: ‚ÄúAlthough the episodes were short, we threw in as many gameplay elements as possible. Although it is recognized now, 11 years later, there was online negativity at the time saying, ‚ÄúSelling a demo version at a low price?‚Äù and it received the lowest rating in the MGS series.‚Äù

Already 11 years agoüòÖ This was originally planned to demonstrate the FOX engine and the gameplay of an open world infiltration game. I thought of it as an episode connecting PW and MGSV TPP, to be a bridge for both generations (console and handheld). We were considering

It‚Äôs clear that Hideo Kojima is proud of the work, and it‚Äôs fair because Ground Zeroes was a great‚Äîif not compact‚ÄîMGS experience. The original plan would happen sometime later as Metal Gear Solid V: Definitive Experience was released. It bundles Ground Zeroes and The Phantom Pain into one complete MGS package.

Kojima has moved on from MGS with Death Stranding. A successor‚ÄîDeath Stranding 2‚Äîis due to release in 2025. Whereas the MGS series moves on without Kojima in Metal Gear Solid Delta Snake Eater.
